That is a great explanation which remove all the weird ideas of dead/live cat propagated by so many comcast science documentary or youtube video. The simple explanation of a short pulse wave which is hard to measure because it is a wave, not a particle, make so much sense. The pilot wave which explain the double slit result as the photon interfering only with itself can also be explained better by this short pulse model of the photon.

The confusion of so many is to keep calling photons "particles".
Once we realize that photons are short packets of vibrating energy and understand the implication of fourier analysis which tells us how a short pulse like a square wave is actually the result of a large number of sinusoidal wave, each oscillating at a frequency set to an integer multiple of the fundamental, then many mysterious phenomena suddenly become clear.

A particle can differ from another by it's size or mass. Photons are mass less. Photons distinguish from each other by their frequency which historically could only be perceived thru the wavelength. The laser based clock (recent nobel price of physics) which improve the precision of ceasium clock by many order of magnitude uses the beating created from frequency difference, so they are effectively equivalent to counting each oscillation. The precision then reach the level of femtosecond, which is the time elapsed between each crest of each pulse of the sinusoidal wave that constitute light.

That beating frequency idea predate these high precision clock by decades... see the superheterodyne radio for 100 year old invention. The radar used by police also use the difference in frequency to detect car speed. A car running at 65 mph will reflect the radar pulses at a frequency approximatively 1000 hz higher (Dopler effect) which is easy to measure directly with low cost microcontrollers.

Contrary to the myth often propagated with the double slit experiment, photons can not be measured by any sensor located on either slit. Any measurement would imply extracting a small amount of energy which violate the conservation of energy inherent with the fixed frequency of each photon. In the case of fluorescence, a photon is absorbed by some atom/molecule, some energy is lost (converted to thermal energy, physical vibration) and some random time later, a new photon is emitted at a lower frequency.

That is the only possible case for photon detectors : absorb a given percentage of them using a beam splitter and let go unmolested the majority or absorb all of them and re-emit new photons at lower frequency with random timing, random direction and random polarization (but often fixed frequency depending only on the natural resonant frequency of the fluorescent material).

only in the case of an electron wave does the "spread-out-ness" indicate the uncertainty in position (∆x), because only in the case of an electron wave does the presence of the wave indicate a POSSIBILITY of finding the wave.

for an electron wave, the wave height indicates the probability of finding the electron at that position. when the wavefunction is nonzero (ie when there's an electron wave), this means that there's a wide range of locations at which the electron might be found. thus ∆x is high.

by contrast, when an ocean wave is spread out, this "spread-out-ness" doesn't impact the uncertainty in the ocean wave's position, because the height isn't saying "the particle might be here." we know exactly where an ocean wave is: it's at a variety of positions, as indicated by the wave height along those positions. it makes no sense to suggest that "because the ocean wave is really spread out, there's a wide range of locations where it might 'materialize' upon being measured.

Your example is incorrect. Uncertainty principle of location and speed is not perceived in the everyday classical world. Only in quantum mechanics. Moreover, uncertainty principle is not a relation between velocity and location. It is generic to 2 properties of a system of a particle that share a specific feature. For example: "Energy and time" or "location and momentum". Anyway it is not location and velocity. Moreover - the uncertainty principle is much simpler than what you describe. It says that 2 properties has uncertainty - means that when you try to measure one property you change the other one. For example, in order to exactly measure the location, you need to pinpoint the particle ("grab it", or put it into a temporary tiny cage). But when you do it, you inevitably affect its momentum (velocity), because by "grabbing" it in a specific point, you don't allow it to move with its current velocity. In classical world there is no such principle because you can measure a location of something without interfering with its speed. For example take a picture of a "car" in a specific place while it drives. Taking a picture is a passive measurement action which does not affect the cars momentum. But in quantum mechanic realm this action is not passive. You have to "grab" the particle to measure its exact location so you also change other properties.

As a result- the wavepulse that he's drawn has a particular uncertainty in space AND a particular uncertainty in frequency. So- you can't know both frequency and position exactly because as you reduce the uncertainty in one- the uncertainty in the other becomes greater! (if you want to know more just look up Fourier Transforms- that's the maths behind it)

-so it maybe isn't perfectly explained- you're right, the wavepulse has a frequency- well- it actually has a range of them. In order to make a wavepulse you have to add together a number of waves with different frequencies. A perfect pulse (just a single spike) can be considered to be made up of an equal amount of waves at every single frequency- that is- it's frequency is completely uncertain. But the wavepulse he's drawn is somewhere in between a perfect pulse and a perfect wave.

..and this is true classically too, it's not even a quantum thing: if you calculate the kinetic energy of a wave it turns out to be proportional to the frequency squared. And momentum is proportional to the square root of the kinetic energy. So momentum is directly proportional to frequency. :)
The momentum of a wave is actually related to it's frequency: It's actually proportional to 1/wavelength. Look up De Broglie wavelength :)

This reply is a little misleading. The Observer Effect is the result of altering the behavior or state of an object as a direct result of your method of observation. For instance, bouncing electrons off of particles to study them causes the velocity of the particles to change.

The Uncertainty Principle is mathematical, not observational, so the act of *predicting* a particle's location and velocity is still impossible. Not due to you altering anything, simply as its natural state of being.

Showing the visual results of a mathematical principle is directly relevant. The purpose of quantum mechanics is to explain the universe. If you exclude all observable examples of its influence you defeat the purpose. Just because it's mathematical doesn't mean that it can't be represented visually. In fact, this is proven repeatedly throughout most, if not all, levels of mathematics.

The uncertainty principle has nothing to do with knowledge of momentum and position.  It has to do with the inherent randomness of those things.  A given particle has a probability spread over momentum and position.  The more variation there is in its possible location, the less variation in its momentum.  That's it.

@marcool108 Actually the uncertainty principle applies to every couple of operators, operators being the stuff physicists use to describe properties of anything. The uncertainty principle states that the product of the uncertainties of 2 operators is proportional to their commutation relation (--> [x,p] = x*p - p*x). If this equals 0, there is no limit to certainty. If it doesn't, there is a lower bound to the product of the variances of your operators.

@thenameissammy Think of it like watching a boat on a lake. You can tell from shore where the boat is, but if it's moving you'll have to keep watching the boat if you always want to know its exact location. Otherwise all you can do is imagine a line in the direction the boat's moving, and guess where it will be from its last known location and your estimate of its speed. If you're measuring -exactly- where the boat is, it's hard to measure its speed (frequency). And that's uncertainty!

@traillife 

This is not the point at all! The fact that you need some sort of exchange (you mention energy/temperature exchange) in a measurement is NOT central to the uncertainty principle. In your example, we can make the thermometer arbitrarily light or give it an initial temperature arbitrarily close to the temperature of the coffee, and thus make the measurement affect the system arbitrarily little. The uncertainty principle sets a lower bound to this arbitrariness.

The idea is that sometimes you can't measure something without affecting the measurement. If you wanted to measure the temperature of a cup of coffee at a given time and you put a thermometer in the cup of coffee the thermometer would affect the temperature, either absorbing heat from the coffee or the coffee would absorb heat from the thermometer, changing the temperature from what it was at the given time you wanted to measure it.

@pacman211 Its actually a property of quantum mechanics regarding relative motion of electrons in an electron cloud of an atom. It says that we can't simultaneously find the position and velocity of an electron. If we find out its position, we don't have an idea where the particle is and in which direction is it going.

So there's a limit to how much we can KNOW about a tiny particle like the electron, but the particle itself has both location and velocity.  Like the famous cat, it is truly either alive or dead, not both, we simply can't tell.

Stephen Hawking explained it with particles. When you want to see where a particle is, you can use low frequency light to measure its position, but you can only measure it as precisely as is the wavelength of the light. If you use high frequency light, though, the light hitting the particle changes its speed so you don't know its speed so accurately.
